abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcomes were satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though institutional development
            impacts only modest. Lessons reinforce the notion that
            institutional reform is a long-term, and difficult process,
            that requires difficult policy decisions. In this case,
            reforms meant that the Ministry of Rural Development was to
            reduce its control over the Institute of Rural Economy
            (IER), and the National Agricultural Research Council
            (CNRA), while ownership of vast plots of productive land
            would be transferred from the Ministry of Finance to IER -
            in a country where land pressures are increasing - and,
            various ministries would loose control on IER as a large
            employer. In such an environment, time to implement
            institutional changes needs to be carefully evaluated;
            regrettably, the project was overly optimistic, and,
            covenants and conditions of disbursements, are not efficient
            mechanisms to prod profound changes. Instead, a detailed
            road map, stipulating precise steps, and expected results
            should have been in place, to ease complex supervision.
            Moreover, regardless of the appropriately selected project
            indicators, these were never used to monitor progress, and
            impacts; neither was the farm level impact of new
            technologies followed, to prioritize research efforts, thus
            resulting in a technology, based on proxy indicators, with
            little knowledge of the actual constraints of such
            technologies. This highlights the fact that a demand-driven
            national system for technology generation, transfer, and
            training, needs to unite all interested parties, taking into
            account related activities, and strengthening producer
            organizations, nongovernmental organizations, and private
            sector service providers.
